instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.PPVCCIO_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCIO_S0_CPU? PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is a power rail responsible for powering the part of the CPU responsible for communicating with other portions of the machine prior to PPVCORE_S0_CPU being present and must be present before vcore, PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is present when the machine is in an on, RUNNING state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't boot
threads.message:
Hey guys. I got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that was liquid damaged and said to not turn on. When I tested it the board did boot, but only display's image to an external monitor and was showing a flashing folder icon. I was able to see the SSD in disk utility so I think it just does not have an OS installed on it. I booted with a test hard drive and it booted into the OS fine but only showed image on external monitor. USB activity was working so I replaced <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> to see if that would fix the issue. Now the board does not seem to boot fully anymore. I do not get image on internal or external monitor anymore and caps lock does not respond. The board is showing that it is using 19.9v and 1.2 amps, both the CPU and GPU are getting warm and the fans are spinning normally. I checked all my S0 rails and they all appear to be present so i'm not sure what could be wrong. I replaced <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> a second time to see if there was any change but it is the same. Here are some of the values I got for my S0 rails.

<SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.963v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0v (Also shows 0v on a good board)
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 1.1v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 1.068v
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> - 0.593v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_T_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> - 1.196v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_KBD</SIGNAL> - 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_GPU</SIGNAL> - 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_GPU</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_S0SW</SIGNAL> - 0.984v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_T139</SIGNAL> - 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GPU</SIGNAL> - 0.904v
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCI_S0_GPU</SIGNAL> - 0.901v
PP1V5R1V35_S0_GPU_MEM - 1.348v
PP1V5R1V35_S0_GPU_IC - 1.349v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> - 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't boot
threads.message:
Did you test USB activity again?

Something happened when you've changed the <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>.
Did you try same chip again?
You should get external video at least.

Check for knocked off, or moved components.
Heat applied to the board could affected CPU and even damaged it.

Which was initial area afected by liquid spill?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't boot
threads.message:
Yes I did test usb activity using a USB drive and the light does not turn on and I am not getting external video. I tried 2 new <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> chips with no change and I did compare diode mode reading around the LCD connector with another good board and the only value that is slightly different is <SIGNAL>LCD_IRQ_L</SIGNAL>, which measures .477 on this board and .490 on a good board. I will check for some knocked off components.

This board was pretty nasty when I opened it up. There was some sticky substance all over the board, that almost looked like someone has rubbed Vaseline all over the board. The hardest hit area was on the UB300/400 side of the board but there was also some on the middle section of the board. I have included some images I took of the board when I first opened it. I do not have a UC so I cleaned the board thoroughly using rubbing alcohol and I tested it was still booting to external after that.

[ATTACH type="full" width="30%"]56218._xfImport[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full" width="30%"]56221._xfImport[/ATTACH]
[ATTACH type="full" width="30%"]56223._xfImport[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full" width="30%"]56227._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't boot
threads.message:
I checked and I'm not getting the voltage for the screen but <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> is 1.35v. When I tested <SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> on my other working board, it initially goes to 1.35v in the first few seconds after connecting the charger, but then it drops to 0v for a few seconds before going up to steady 3.3v. This board seems to get stuck in the stage where that voltage is only 1.35v. Wondering if I should replace <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> or not since I do not even get caps lock to work.

<SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>LCD_MUX_SEL</SIGNAL> - 1.35v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PANEL_FET_EN_DLY</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> -0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't boot
threads.message:
I can only think on damaged CPU in the process of changing <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>.
Or maybe some components, or traces related with CPU activity.
A simple video issue shouldn't block USB activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't boot
threads.message: I decided to try another USB drive to make sure that there was no activity and this drive does light up when the charger is connected so this board does seem to have some USB activity. I also tried a USB Bluetooth adapter and the led on that also lights up when plugged into the board. The heatsink on this board does get very hot after only connected for a few minutes so idk if that mean the CPU is dead or not. I have replaced <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> on other 1707's before and never damaged a CPU in the process but I guess its always possible.
